headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Special Prosecutor In Trump's GA Election Case Testifies On Personal Matters And Financial Struggles. Aired 2-2:30p ET

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The specific reason that that specific date was selected was because she was only in town for the brief.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Your honor. This is the trademark privilege.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Why he decided to file this and why do you have the right to object on his behalf for attorney-client privilege?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Because, well, I don't.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: All right, there we go.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And I believe that he's already attempted to answer this question and there was no privilege raised, so he's given a partial answer and now he's about to finish that. So first of all, I don't think it's covered by attorney-client privilege and I'll deal with that if you want me to, but otherwise he's already answered part of it so he doesn't get to say now to stop, so.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Well, it was a long preface but I don't think it ever actually got to what you should have been at issue there. So, if you can lay the foundation we'll deal with the objection.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, take a step back. Okay, you realize that an attorney- client privilege is the privilege of the client, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you, in connection with your representation, at least it's been proffered to the court by Mr. Bradley that it's up to you to decide whether you want to raise the privilege, right? WADE

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: It's not up to Mr. Bradley.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So you have the power in order to get to the truth of the matter. You have the power to waive the attorney-client privilege, do you not?ANNA GREEN CROSS, ATTORNEY FOR FULTON COUNTY DA'S OFFICE: I believe that's an inappropriate question. The privilege is there.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Whether he uses it or not, it doesn't matter why. Mr. Sano, I think if we're trying to get to the answer to your question, let's figure out whether it covers the question you were trying to get to.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And your honour, if I may finish, and your position is you have no intention of waiving your attorney-client privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. Can you answer the question why you waited until November 2nd, the day after you were hired by Ms. Willis to file for divorce?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I can. Okay. So, again, Joycelyn had relocated to Texas, and she had been in Texas for months. She was only here for a brief period of time to drive my daughter's car back with her. And when she came here to do that, I was able to then get her served.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So, your answer as to why you waited until the day after you were hired by Ms. Willis, on which would be November 1st, 2021, to file the claim for the divorce on November 2nd, 2021, your testimony under oath is because your wife was here.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Was here. But had not been here in October, had not been here in September, had not been here in August of 2021. She had been in Texas taking care of her ailing mother and an aging father.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So your testimony --

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So, the first opportunity that I had after speaking with my lawyers to take care of that, was the date it was filed and served because she happened to be here. It had nothing to do with-- that was purely coincidental, that contract.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I understand that its pure coincidence to your testimony(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: And understand that this was by agreement because she and I. She being my wife and I, that we would divorce when the kids matriculated out and that that would have actually been an agreement attached to the filing. It became apparent that the agreement wasn't going to happen and things got a little contentious so that's when the privilege will kick in. And then I was forced to do it when I did it.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, if I understood correctly, again, you tell me if I'm wrong, is it your testimony that your wife was not in Atlanta, Georgia, or the metro area throughout October of 2021?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So she was, at least on some occasions, in the Atlanta area.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: But that was during the time when we were working through the consent agreement that that fell through.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Again, I think we're pretty far afield on relevance. The answer to the question about the timing of the divorce filling and--

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Understood, Ms. Cross. Mr. Sadow, where are we going from here?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: We're about to finish this area since I'm not going to be able to go any further about -- if we want to call the ex, we'll call the ex for that purpose.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Well, we might have to discuss whether that's a collateral issue altogether.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just saying if, I didn't say we will, but we --

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. So, you said that you were aware of the contracts that Mr. Bradley and Mr. Campbell had with the Fulton County District Attorney's Office, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And how did you become aware of those?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Just through conversation, they told me.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: With who? Conversation with who?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Bradley and Mr. Campbell.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So you were discussing matters with Mr. Bradley which were not related to attorney-client privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Related to the contract, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. But you were having conversations that would not, even though if I understood correctly, Mr. Bradley was your attorney at the time, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: At what time? SADOW

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Is that the date of his contract?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Pretty close.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I don't know what the date of his contract was, but if it was after the date of the filing of divorce, then yeah.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm not talking about after the date of the filing of divorce. It's been represented to the court that you had an attorney-client relationship with Mr. Bradley from 2015 forward. Yes, sir. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. That is correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: When Mr. Bradley received his contract with Fulton County, that was in 2021, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: We can prove that through other evidence. But at the time that Mr. Bradley was doing work for Fulton County, if I understand, you still had an attorney-client privilege, at least you're claiming one, with Mr. Bradley, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, when you talked to Mr. Bradley about matters with his contract in Fulton County, those were not covered by your attorney- client privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: They were not.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. And that meant that not all communications with Mr. Bradley were covered by attorney-client privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Well, those certainly weren't.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: My question was, not all communications with Mr. Bradley were covered by, at least as you've been represented to the court, by the attorney-client privilege. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Those communications were not.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, there were communications outside of the attorney-client privilege, correct? With Mr. Bradley?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: If you're asking me if I ever communicated with him outside of the attorney-client privilege, the answer is yes. Okay. I communicated with him outside the attorney-client privilege.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Let's finish this up. And I'm going to go back to my question. Did you call it Roman number four, which is defense? Okay. In defense exhibit number four, Mr. Gillen went over with you your responses to certain interrogatories on May the 30th, 2023. Remember that?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Not going back into those, the words in the interrogatories are already in evidence, so we're not going to do that. But the ones that we've got that we've gone into, there were two of them. And your answer to both of those was none. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Now, on January 25th of 2024, --

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, Sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: -- you again were in a position that you answered those same interrogatories, the two that we're talking about. I can get specific if we need to, but as long as we understand we're talking about the same two. Right?WADE? Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So, they are in defense exhibit number six, and they are interrogatories number four and number five.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Okay. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No, I want you to be able to see it. So, it's a defense exhibit number six.WADE I don't-

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I see you have six up there.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm told that you have six.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. You would agree with me that in defense exhibit number six, and we're talking about interrogatories of January 25, 2024.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That as to interrogatory number four, that's the same interrogatory, same words that were in the interrogatory that Mr. Gillen went over, which was dated May 30th of 2023. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And your original response in defense exhibit number six was none. Correct?WADE Yes, sir. SADOW:  Your updated response was the plaintiff declines to respond to this interrogatory and asserts his privilege pursuant to OCGA section 24-5-505. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You know that 24-5-505 breaks down into two, two privileges, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Which is why I was specific. I said I asserted the privacy privilege.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Well, that's what I'm asking you. In your updated response, there's no reference to privacy, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, there is. In the code section 24-5-505.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, but it also--

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Refers to privacy.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Just go with me, okay? That code section says, does it not, no party or witness shall be required to testify as to any matter which may incriminate or tend to incriminate such parties or witness or which shall tend to bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon such party or witness. You'd agree with that, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I'm not reading it.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I'm not reading it. I don't have it in front of me.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOW
utterances.sentences: If I may. Mr. Sano, I can take judicial notice. That is what the rule says. If you want to ask him any follow-up questions.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, thank you. You are not claiming that your answer to number four in Raga 24 on January 25th, 2024 incriminates you, that is, as in Fifth Amendment privilege, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You're claiming the second part, that it would bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt, correct?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to that. I don't think that's the full thing. And also, the witness doesn't have it in front of him, so I don't know how he's going to respond to that. He has said several times privacy is largely in focus at such times.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Overruled.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Claiming privacy.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: The privilege that you make reference to is to infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon the witness, right? Or party. That's the section that you were relying on, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's what it says, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I could show you, but I think the court has already indicated he can take judicial notice of the statute. So, assume that what I'm telling you is accurate, okay?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. How would an answer of, of none, bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon you?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: So, as I explained in direct of Mr. Roman's counsel, the minute she elected to intervene into my divorce proceeding, I then started to understand the bigger picture, which was that all the attorneys in the election interference case were colluding with Joycelyn's divorce lawyer. And because of that, I said, privacy. I don't want my divorce proceeding to bleed into this criminal proceeding. I just didn't want that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, you raised a privilege, if I understand, that indicated that your answer would bring infamy, disgrace, or public contempt upon you, right?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, I'm going to object to the relevance of this and ask an answer several times.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Mr. Sadow, where are we heading with this?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I think I can finish that up by saying, you didn't say none again. You asserted a privilege, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you did the same thing, did you not, with number five?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That is, you didn't say none again, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Is the answer to the interrogatory number four, if you have it in front of you, is the answer none? Is that the truth?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The answer is, to that interrogatory, is as I placed it at the time I responded, sir. That's the answer.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I am asking you now is the answer to that interrogatory is none.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The answer is still privilege.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So, he's apparently electing to apply the same privilege, Mr. Sadow, to that exact same question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And I have a case which indicates that we can get beyond that if the court deems that appropriate.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And to what end? To what end?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That the privilege actually does not apply and he must answer the question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No, I think it would prove-- I think if he is forced or compelled to answer the question, he will either answer it falsely by saying none or he'll answer it truthfully by saying yes and then telling us what it is. That's what I believe, that's why I'm asking.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: But the interrogator you're referring to, though the question contained there--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: -- two interrogatories, yes sir--

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's the entertaining one, it's whether there are other relationships, right?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: with the specific language that's in the interrogatories.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Sure, haven't you already covered that in all the other questions that we've had so far?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: We have, but again, the court could, if I could, require a compelling answer from him as to whether his answer would still be none, then we would know whether or not he was telling the truth.Now, if the answer is no, then obviously there was a time in the past where he was not. It simply requires him to now answer under oath what he refused to answer and claimed, what I might suggest is a bogus privilege, and that you can pierce that privilege because it's a material fact in connection with this case. Again, it's a call that your honour makes. I have case law that says you can do that but it's your discretion.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Ms Cross?

utterances.speaker: CORSS
utterances.sentences: Your honour, Mr has been on the stand now for several hours, he's been asked and answered very personal questions that I believe cover the issues as Mr. Sadow is making his argument, and this is probably an argument to make for the -- later to the court and not a question to propound.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So, as I see it, the only relevance these interrogatories have to this case really whatsoever would be as either prior inconsistent or consistent statements and to that and I think the question has been put to him again and again and again, he's answered how he believes he felt his answer should be and why he answered a certain way. And as it goes to credibility, I think at this point we're arguing weight and I don't really see the value in pushing this issue further.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, all right, well just for the record the case that I was going to refer to is State versus Wakefield at 324 Georgia Appeal 587. And specifically, it would be 590 in which they talk about this specific privilege. This is a 2013 case and then a footnote to numbers, footnote 3 and footnote 3 says there are times when the materiality of the evidence outweighs the testimonial privilege, and it goes and explains what that is that's what I'm bringing.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And I see what you're saying that we could say that you need to answer the question regardless of the privilege you asserted. At this point though, I think we've covered that ground and we're ready to move on.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, based on that I have nothing else, thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Okay, Mr. McCulloch, anything on behalf of Mr. Floyd moving through defense counsel? No, no, I'm looking behind you, Mr. McCulloch on behalf of Mr. Floyd, he's elbowing you, sir. Okay, um, Mr. Cromwell?

utterances.speaker: CROMWEL
utterances.sentences: Nothing your honour.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: All right.  Ms. Cross.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Mr. Wade, have you still got exhibit number 14 in front of you, one with all of the invoices?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I believe I have them all.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. So, you were asked, Mr. Wade, about a couple of the invoice items and your testimony, I think was that the percentage of income post special counsel appointment in November 2021, the percentage of your income, roughly after that time, was about 50-50 Fulton versus other income from your law practice, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Roughly, yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Okay, sometimes more, sometimes less?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. How about your time? I'm interested in the percentage of your time from, from November 2021 to let's say the close of the special purpose grand gala jury when it was dissolved in January 2023. You estimate for us the percentage of your time that was spent on Fulton County work versus other work.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Oh gosh, 99-1. 99% of the time here in this building, working on this case.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right, it was, as I understood your testimony, it was an intense period in terms of hours while that special purpose grand jury was meeting, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And who was head or manager of the election integrity case during that time for the district attorney's office?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I was.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You were coordinating the efforts?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You don't need to go all through it, but is your representation that 99.9% of the time that's restricted to 2022, 99% of your professional working time was devoted to this case?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And the remainder, whatever it was, was to some of your other cases that were ongoing?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. All right.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: 2022, I want to focus on that a little bit because if we are looking at, I believe, the financial affidavits, do you have those in front of you as well?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: The financial affidavit that was filed in your divorce case in January 2022, you estimated your monthly income at that time was $14,000 a month, right?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: January '22.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: January 23, what did that number come to?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: What about 2024?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Is that there in front of you? That's not one of the ones that's there in front of you?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. So as reflected in those financial affidavits, your income decreased as a result of your work in this case, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Significantly.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: The structure of your firm, we talked a lot about that and I don't want to go through it anymore than we need to, but 2022, the structure of your firm changed, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. In the early part of 2022, there were three of you, you and Mr. Campbell and Mr. Bradley, you split expenses. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And you profit shared among yourselves, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: After Mr. Bradley left the firm, then there were just two of you, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That is the cause of the significant change, yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: So now you have two people bringing in income, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And one of those people, you, is spending almost all of your time devoted to this election integrity case, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. Correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And your income from this election integrity case is less than what it was the year before?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: We talked about the monthly caps, or we didn't talk about it, there was talk about the monthly cap that was included in your contracts indicating there was a certain threshold that you could reach, number of hours a month, and over that amount, you were not going to be compensated, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. And you kind of smiled when you said that. That's a little bittersweet there, isn't it? WADE

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. Exhibit 14, is that still there in front of you?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I want you to take a look, please. That's a collection of exhibits that includes all of your invoices, as was represented. I want you to take a look at invoice number nine.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Is that there in front of you?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I have it.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Invoice number nine, Mr. Wade, indicates that you performed hours of work that you were not compensated for because your cap had been reached?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: YES, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: I want you to take a look. And what did you do in those circumstances, when the hours that you worked per month were more than the cap that was in your contract that you were permitted to be paid for?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I was forced to lose that time. I didn't get paid for it.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Okay. And that's what exhibit number nine shows?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. And in exhibit number nine, you've got a task hours that were completed and you just didn't bill for it. You noted the time and then a zero beside it because you didn't bill the county for that time.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. What about exhibit number, invoice number 13? Can you flip to that for me?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I have it.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Is that a similar situation?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. It is.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And what is it on exhibit number, I'm sorry, invoice number 13?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I don't know. This invoice makes me cry. There's so many hours here that I worked that I couldn't get paid for.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And you worked those hours anyway, Mr. Wade? WADE

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Can you look at invoice number 23 for me there in exhibit number 14?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Does that reflect a similar situation, the hours worked that you were not compensated for?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Invoice number 24 and 27. Can you take a look at those? And let us know if that reflects the same situation?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Are you trying to depress me looking at the money --

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: No. Look at the money

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Okay, and there's no work-around to that. You didn't attempt to work around that contractual cap on your hours?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Oh no, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All right. You were asked a lot of questions, Mr. Wade, about the affidavit that was submitted, correct? Do you recall those questions?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, I'm stuck on this invoice. You know, if I was going to get a benefit, I'd like that benefit. That's the one I want. That didn't happen.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Okay, all right, and there was no renegotiating your contract to reflect that those hours should be paid, right?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: No, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Okay, all right. Do you have your affidavit there in front of you?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: The affidavit, of course, was attached to and provided in support of the state's response to Mr. Roman's motion, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am. CROSS

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You signed that affidavit?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: All of the allegations and the representations in that affidavit are true, is that right, Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Every one of them.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Every one of them. You were asked a lot of questions about our line number 34, can you turn to that for me, please? It's on page four of that affidavit.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Can you read it out loud for me, please?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: The district attorney and I are both financially independent professionals. Expenses for personal travel were roughly divided equally between us. At times, I have made and purchased travel for District Attorney Willis and myself from my personal funds. At other times, District Attorney Willis has made and purchased travel for she and I from her personal funds. Examples of District Attorney Willis purchasing plane tickets for she and I, with her personal funds, for our personal travel, are attached.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Funds, Mr. Wade. As you understand the term funds, does that include cash?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Does that include credit?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Does that include reimbursements?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You didn't represent in your affidavit, Mr. Wade, that you were including all of the receipts from funds or travel expenses that were paid on your behalf by District Attorney Willis, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: You had, I think your conversation with Ms. Merchant was, you produced the receipt that you had.

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Are you aware of any other receipts? Let me ask you this right now. I put you on the first step. Marcus, that states you're the number one. You testified, Mr. Wade, that District Attorney Willis purchased and funded the entire trip to Bayreuth (ph). That was her treat to you for her birthday?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And you testified that she purchased the plane tickets for you, correct?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: And while you may not have had the receipts on hand when you filled out the affidavit, because they weren't from your possession, are you aware now that there are receipts and that it reflects the District Attorney's--

utterances.speaker: UNKNOW
utterances.sentences: If this is going to go in there, then I'd like to look at it first. I've got a copy.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Okay. Do you remember, Mr. Wade, approximately how much (inaudible). Do you remember how much the flight was for you, your flight to Bayreuth? And if you don't, I'm not tendering it for you, because I'm just asking you to take a look at that and see if that refreshes your recollection as to the amount that that plane ticket cost that was extended by District Attorney. You may keep it. Does that refresh your recollection, Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WADE
utterances.sentences: It does, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Approximately how much was the amount of the ticket that District Attorney Willis purchased for your travel to Bayreuth?
